title.narrative: Hosts for Peace: Schools of Gastronomy, Tourism and Hospitality

description.narrative:
The project contributes to the livelihoods improvement of disadvantaged, displaced and demobilized young people and small holder farmers in the growing agro-food and hospitality market in Colombia. This proposal is centered at generating economic opportunities:
- For disadvantaged youth: job allocation as a way to stimulate their livelihoods, by offering grant technical cooking formation (work oriented skills, knowledge and technical capacity) through the already proved MANQ'A schools program (actually implemented in Bolivia in 14 schools and Colombia in 2 schools). - For the small-scale rural producers: by reaching commercial opportunities of their locally sustainable production (stimulate local economy) through the MANQ'A cooking schools own demand of products and by increasing the demand from an already stablished network with restaurants and other food business in Bogota.
As well, the project impact local consumers that will have access to affordable healthy food produced by the MANQ'A cooks during their formation process. The program seeks innovative ways of providing and promoting healthy food to local consumers for example in local gastronomic markets and fairs.
One of the most innovative elements in the project relates to the mechanisms that ICCO has created to ensure the financial sustainability of the intervention. To do so, MANQ'A creates profitable business models (Catering services, restaurants, food products, etc) that generate its own revenues for the project.
The Host for Peace program identifies in the gastronomy and hospitality sectors an opportunity to generate options for a licit economy for vulnerable young people. Through the training in work in kitchen and hospitality, the young people will have an educational and job opportunities in their territories, so that after their formation they undertake their life projects and are an integral part in the construction of peace in their communities and in the country. The action will select 500 young people (50% women). The training will take place in groups of 25-30 young people. Then, the fulfillment of 600 to 1,000 hours of training by competences is expected, which will focus on technical issues, but also include culture of peace, personal development and psychosocial tools. This model not only increases the employability of the young people or the possibility that they develop business, but also constitutes a scenario of encounter and reconciliation between young people in the process of reintegration, young victims and their receiving communities. The training has a focus on the recovery of local products, the territorial identity and the gastronomic culture of the region, as well as the change of imaginaries and beliefs about the roles of women and men that perpetuate inequality. Thanks to these approaches, young people will be able to recognize themselves as agents of local development through the valorisation of the heritage of the territory, of local products, stimulate local agricultural production and open up marketing and the market for families and young producers, and especially, women can strengthen their economic, social and political autonomy and recognize themselves as agents of change for themselves and their environments.

Through the training in work in kitchen and hospitality, youngsters have the opportunity to have education and work in their territories, so that later they can undertake their life projects and be an integral part in the construction of peace in their communities and in the country. The action will select 500 young people, who will complete 600 hours of training by competences, which will focus on technical issues, but also include culture of peace, personal development and psychosocial tools.

title.narrative: Number of nutrition education/messaging events organized

comment.narrative: Events attended with the foodtruck

1. COVida Strategy (April 21 to 23, 2020 - Putumayo): As a response to the challenges that COVID 19 brought for Host for peace participants and their families, during April of 2020, basic food packages were distributed among them along with lessons to reuse food residues. The goal was to enhance participant's food security. 2. Exhibition of Host for peace in Putumayo to te global CEO (November 2019) 3. "Sazón y Mano Cambiada" meeting in Tumaco (November 2019)

title.narrative: Number of youth reached with vocational training programs

comment.narrative: Results will be reached by mid 2020

2 foodtrucks are designed, for the training of rural youth in gastronomy, tourism and hospitality. In addition, an agreement has been structured with experts from MANQ'A Bolivia for the methodological transfer and an agreement with the Putumayo Technological Institute and the Escuela Taller Tumaco for tutoring and certification. In April, the training process begins in Tumaco (64 young people), Villagarzon (64 young people) and Valle del Sibundoy (62 young people).
Results will be reached by mid 2020

42 young people trained and certified in cooking and hospitality in Colon; 49 young people trained and certified in cooking in Tumaco, urban area; 119 young people trained and certified in cooking at the Villagarzon / Mocoa node;52 young people trained and certified in hospitality in the Villagarzon / Mocoa node. 76 young people trained and certified in bakery and bartender in Tumaco, urban area; 84 young people trained and certified in cooking and hospitality in Ipiales.
Results will be reached by mid 2020

47 young people trained and certified in cooking in Tumaco, urban area; 42 young people trained and certified in cooking and hospitality in Colon; 87 young people trained and certified in cooking at the Villagarzon / Mocoa node; 84 young people trained and certified in hospitality in the Villagarzon / Mocoa node.
Results will be reached by mid 2020
51 young people are being trained at the Gastronomy School in the municipality of Tumaco. In the month of July, the process of formation in Alto Putumayo begins.
Results will be reached by mid 2020

51 young people in the Tumaco municipality are being trained at the Gastronomy School. These students will graduate on December 20. In August, 30 young people joined the training process (gastronomy) in Alto Putumayo. In November, 80 young people joined the hotel training process and 65 the gastronomy training process in the municipalities of Valle de Sibundoy, Mocoa and Villagarzón.

title.narrative: Number of youth employed in sectors gastronomy, tourism and/or hospitality

comment.narrative: The result will be reached by mid 2020
Corresponde al total de empleos reportados en la línea de salida dentro de los sectores relevantes y en los municipios de intervención del proyecto
The result will be reached by mid 2020
In August, the first cohort of the training process will be held in Tumaco (64 young people), Villagarzon (64 young people) and Valle del Sibundoy (62 young people).
The result will be reached by mid 2020

It will advance once the students finish their education process. In August, the graduation of the first group of the training process will be held in Tumaco (51 young people, representing the same number of families) and the process of formation in the Alto Putumayo will start in the month of July.
The result will be reached by mid 2020

The indicator will advance once students finish their education process. In December, the graduation of the first group of the training process will be held in Tumaco (51 young people, representing the same number of families). The training process in Alto Putumayo began in August and in Medio Putumayo in November.

comment.narrative: 5% of the 500 youth

title.narrative: Number of women with improved knowledge on healthy diets

comment.narrative: 35% of the 500 youth
The exposed data is from the exit line survey applied to graduates of gastronomy training. All of them received at least 20 hours of training in healthy nutrition.

title.narrative: Number of men with improved knowledge on healthy diets

comment.narrative: 35% of the 500 youth
The exposed data is from the exit line survey applied to graduates of gastronomy training. All of them received at least 20 hours of training in healthy nutrition.
60% of the 500 youth
The data exposed is from the exit line survey, and the income generation area of Hosts for Peace has complemented it.

title.narrative: Number of men with improved dietary diversity

comment.narrative: 30% of the 500 youth

The exposed data is from the exit line survey applied to graduates. Participants certified in short-term courses haven't taken the survey yet. Only those participants enrolled in gastronomy training answered questions regarding improved diets. Answers considered were literally "I eat healthier now" and is because of Host for Peace.

title.narrative: Number of people with an increase in income

comment.narrative: 50% of the 500 youth

title.narrative: Number of women with improved dietary diversity

comment.narrative: 30% of the 500 youth

The exposed data is from the exit line survey applied to graduates. Participants certified in short-term courses haven't taken the survey yet. Only those participants enrolled in gastronomy training answered questions regarding improved diets. Answers considered were literally "I eat healthier now" and is because of Host for Peace.

title.narrative: Number of households with improved food security

comment.narrative: 60% of the 500 youth

The exposed data is from the exit line survey applied to graduates. Participants certified in short-term courses haven't taken the survey yet. Only those participants enrolled in gastronomy training answered questions regarding their house food security. Answers considered were literally "I replicate what I learn in Hosts for Peace in my house" since Hosts for Peace teaches strategies to enhance food security.
